fr:title.text: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These are mostly inspired by Zwart and Marsden's research into no-go theorems for distributive laws between algebraic theories [zwartmarsden2022].

I've been roughly translating properties of algebraic theories into the language of monad containers (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}), by considering:
Shapes s : S as "terms"
Positions p : P\ s as "free variables in the term s"
\iota as a "generic variable placeholder"
\sigma as a "generalised substitution"
\text {pr} as a "reindexing" of positions after a "substitution" This is not meant to be an exact translation; the idea is to get inspiration for properties of monad containers we might want to consider when proving things about monad container distributive laws.
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) satisfies the singleton property if P\ \iota \cong 1. All cartesian monad containers have this property by definition.

A property of algebraic theories that is used implicitly in [zwartmarsden2022] is commutativity of disjoint substitutions, i.e. given terms s, s_0 and a substitution f where for all y, x 
otin 	ext {var}(f(y)) we always have that: s[s_0/x][f(y) / y 
eq x] = s[f(y) / y 
eq x][s_0/x]

The List monad container \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} satisfies this, which makes sense since it can also be represented by an algebraic theory. This also holds for coproduct, reader (trivially), state, writer, and probably many others!
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) has a constant shape if there exists some s_0 : S where P\ s_0 \cong 0.
Notice that all functions P\ s_0 \to S are equal to \lambda \_ . \iota , since P\ s_0 is propositional and pointed (and therefore contractible).

This holds for \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} for example: take n to be any natural number greater than 0, take f := \lambda \_ . 0, and then given some x : \text {Fin}\ n we have \sum _{i = 0}^{n} f^x\ i = 1. Notice that this property holds for all n with non-empty position sets, so \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} actually satisfies a stronger condition (analogous to Zwart and Marsden's S4 [zwartmarsden2022]).
This also holds for state, by taking s = \text {id} and f = \lambda \_ . \text {id}.

Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers. A monad container morphism is a container morphism u \triangleleft v : S \triangleleft P \to T \triangleleft Q such that:
\begin {align*} u\ \iota ^S &= \iota ^T\\ u\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f) &= \sigma ^T\ (u\ s)\ (u \circ f \circ v)\\ \text {pr}^S_1\ (v\ q) &= v\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\\ \text {pr}^S_2\ (v\ q) &= v\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q) \end {align*}
These are in bijection with monad maps between the monad container extensions of the relevant monad containers.

If (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) are cartesian, we also get that:
\begin {align*} \text {pr}^{-1^{S}}\ (v\ q , v\ q^\prime ) = v\ (\text {pr}^{-1^{T}}\ (q , q^\prime )) \end {align*}

Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers and (u_1 , u_2 , v_1 , v_2) be a monad container distributive law of type T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P \Rightarrow S \triangleleft P \circ T \triangleleft Q.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be extended to a fully faithful functor from the category of monad containers and monad container maps to the category of \mathbf {Set}-monads and monad maps. [uustalu2017]

An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to A) \to A, satisfying: \begin {align*} \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a) &= a\\ \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p)) \end {align*}

The Coproduct monad container for a set E is given by the data 1 + E \triangleleft T where T\ (\text {inl}\ *) := 1, T\ (\text {inr}\ \_) := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {inl}\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inl}\ *)\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f &:= \text {inr}\ e\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is the unique monad container structure that you can give the container 1 + E \triangleleft T [uustalu2017]. This also happens to be a cartesian monad container. \text {pr} is well-defined up to function extensionality by induction on its implicit arguments.

The List monad container is given by the data \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= 1\\ \sigma \ n\ f &:= \sum _{i = 0}^n f\ i\\ \text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= \text {greatest } i \in \lbrack 0 .. n \rparen \text { where } \sum _{j = 0}^i f\ j \leq m \\ \text {pr}_2\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= m - (\sum _{j = 0}^{\text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m} f\ j) \end {align*}

The Maybe monad can be represented as the monad container 2 \triangleleft T where T\ \text {true} := 1, T\ \text {false} := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {true}\\ \sigma \ \text {true}\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ \text {false}\ f &:= \text {false}\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is a special case of the Coproduct monad container.
It might be possible to change the type of the shapes to some M-type to allow for this monad container to be definable in MLTT for example.

A random unorganised thought: since there seems to be some connection between the State monad container and the S(K?)I combinator calculus, maybe \sigma here can act as different interpretation of the S combinator?
Interestingly it seems to consist of the combinators S (a version with flipped arguments) and I. Is there some deeper connection to combinatory logic here?

The Writer monad container for a monoid (A, \otimes , e) is given by the data A \triangleleft \lambda \_ . 1 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= e\\ \sigma \ a\ b\ &:= a \otimes (b\ *)\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (*, *) \end {align*}

Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad containers. It is cartesian iff P\ \iota \cong 1 and \text {pr} is an isomorphism. This is equivalent to saying that the extension of the monad container is a cartesian monad (container functors always preserve pullbacks).
These can also be seen as proper (1,\Sigma ) type universes (Tarski-style).
Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers. They are in bijection with compatible compositions of monad containers.

fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.

fr:title.text: There is only one representable monad container

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is only one representable monad container

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given the container 1 \triangleleft \lambda \_ . A, we look at the required data for a monad container. \iota and \sigma \ a\ b are trival (both are elements of 1). The equations for \text {pr} force it to be defined as the diagonal map: \text {pr}\ a := (a , a)

Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The equations for \text {pr} holds given the first equation. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads (w.r.t. cartesian product) for container functors. [uustalu2017]

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
